descriptions.content:
Nominal clauses function like any noun phrase: as a subject, object, complement, etc. The nominalized verb (or proposition) becomes the head of the noun phrase; that is, it operates as a noun and may be followed by a demonstrative and case marker like any other noun.

Like relative clauses (xxlink 26.3.1), nominal clauses are also formed with the use of a nominalizer, but it is important to distinguish between these two types of clauses. Whereas relative clauses modify a head noun much like an adjective, nominal clauses function as nouns. Tibetan nominal clauses use the nominalizers པ་, ཡག་, and རྒྱུ་. They may be followed by the genitive or oblique case (when the function of the clause requires it).

The syntactic position of the nominal clause in the sentence depends on its function as subject, object, or complement. In this first example, the nominal clause is the complement of the noun རེ་བ་:

  • ཁྱེད་རང་ཕེབས་ཐུབ་པའི་རེ་བ་ཡོད། “I hope you’ll be able to come.”

In the next example, the nominal clause is the object of the verb སྨོན་འདུན་ཞུ་:

  • རང་སློབ་སྦྱོང་ཡག་པོ་དང་གཟུགས་པོ་བདེ་ཐང་ཡོང་ཡག་སྨོན་འདུན་ཞུ་རྒྱུ་ཡིན། “I pray that you should be in good health and that you study well.”

Here, the nominal clause is the object of the verb ཤེས་:

  • བུ་མོ་དེ་མོ་རང་རང་གི་ཨ་ལྕག་ཡིན་པ་ཤེས་པ་རེད། “She realized that the girl was her own sister.”

Finally, in these examples, the noun phrase is the object of the verb བསམ་:

  • ཁོང་གིས་བོད་པ་ཚང་མ་སྐྱོ་པོ་ཡིན་པ་བསམ་པ་རེད་པས། “Did he think all Tibetans were poor?”
  • ཁོང་གིས་བོད་པ་ཚང་མ་སྐྱོ་པོ་རེད་བསམ་པ་རེད་པས། “Did he think all Tibetans were poor?”
